summary: This document is a July 17, 2008 letter from attorney Bradley Edwards to an Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) regarding the proposed stipulated facts in the Jeffrey Epstein case. It outlines multiple points of disagreement and requests, including access to plea agreements, transcripts, and FBI reports, and challenges the government's handling of victim notifications and confidentiality provisions. An enclosed July 3, 2008 letter from Edwards and Jay Howell urges federal prosecution of Epstein.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.role: Attorney for victims Jane Doe #1 and Jane Doe #2
persons.context: Author of the main letter, representing victims of Jeffrey Epstein and negotiating with the U.S. Attorney's Office over stipulated facts and victim rights.

persons.name: Jay Howell
persons.context: Co-counsel working with Bradley Edwards on the case, based in Jacksonville, Florida.

persons.name: Paul Cassell
persons.context: Co-counsel working with Bradley Edwards on the case, based in Salt Lake City, Utah.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case, described as a sexual predator who reached a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Jane Doe #1
persons.context: A victim represented by Bradley Edwards, who was met by FBI agents on October 26, 2007, and notified of the case resolution.

persons.name: Jane Doe #2
persons.context: Another victim represented by Bradley Edwards, added to the case, for whom the attorney seeks protections under the agreement with Epstein.

persons.name: Meg Garvin
persons.context: Attorney at the National Crime Victims' Law Institute, whose recollection of events was cited by Professor Cassell.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: The primary government prosecutor addressed in the letter, with whom Edwards is negotiating. The name is redacted in the text.

connections.description: Edwards is the legal representative for victim Jane Doe #1.
Edwards is the legal representative for victim Jane Doe #2.
Edwards and Howell are working together as co-counsel on the Epstein case.
Edwards and Cassell are working together as co-counsel on the Epstein case.
The AUSA's office reached a non-prosecution agreement with Epstein in 2007.
Edwards is negotiating and challenging the AUSA's office over victim rights and case handling.

events.title: Initial Non-Prosecution Agreement Reached
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office reached an initial agreement with Epstein's attorneys to resolve the federal case, containing a confidentiality provision.

events.title: FBI Meeting with Jane Doe #1
events.description: Special Agents met with Jane Doe #1 to explain the investigation was resolved, Epstein would plead guilty to state charges, register as a sex offender, and make concessions for victim damages.

events.title: Victim Notification Sent
events.description: AUSA sent a victim notification to Jane Doe #1 via her attorney Bradley Edwards, which contained a written explanation of the terms of the agreement with Epstein.

events.title: Letter Urging Federal Prosecution
events.description: Bradley Edwards and Jay Howell sent a letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office urging the Attorney General to file federal indictments against Epstein, citing evidence of abuse of over 100 underage girls.

locations: 500 South Australian Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office reached a confidential non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein in September 2007, which was later modified in October and December 2007.

Victim attorney Bradley Edwards was not informed of the non-prosecution agreement when he contacted the U.S. Attorney's Office in mid-June 2008 to urge federal prosecution, and first learned of it on or after July 9, 2008.

FBI agents met with victim Jane Doe #1 on October 26, 2007, to inform her of the case resolution, but Edwards states his client has a differing recollection of that meeting and requests the FBI report.

Edwards and co-counsel allege in their July 3, 2008 letter that Epstein sexually abused more than 100 underage girls and was 'the most dangerous sexual predator of children that our country has ever seen.'
The correspondence reveals disputes over victim rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA), including access to documents and fair treatment.
